action.action-desc: Mr. King (for himself, Mr. Warner, Mr. Tester, and Mrs. Fischer) introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the Committee on Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs

form.official-title: To provide regulatory easement for lending institutions that enable a vibrant economy.

subsection.text:
This Act may be cited as the
Regulatory Easement for Lending Institutions that Enable a Vibrant Economy Act of 2014
or the RELIEVE Act .
The table of contents for this Act is as follows:

title.header: Expansion of small bank holding company policy statement definition

section.header: Changes required to small bank holding company policy statement on assessment of financial and managerial factors

subsection.text: Before the end of the 6-month period beginning on the date of the enactment of this Act, the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System (hereafter in this Act referred to as the Board) shall publish in the Federal Register proposed revisions to the Small Bank Holding Company Policy Statement on Assessment of Financial and Managerial Factors (12 C.F.R. part 225 appendix C) that provide that the policy shall apply to bank holding companies and savings and loan holding companies which have pro forma consolidated assets of less than $1,000,000,000 and that—

paragraph.text: are not engaged in significant nonbanking activities either directly or through a nonbank subsidiary;
do not conduct significant off-balance sheet activities (including securitization and asset management or administration) either directly or through a nonbank subsidiary; and
do not have a material amount of debt or equity securities outstanding (other than trust preferred securities) that are registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

subsection.text: The Board may exclude any bank holding company or savings and loan holding company, regardless of asset size, from the policy statement under subsection (a) if the Board determines that such action is warranted for supervisory purposes.

section.text: Section 171(b)(5)(C) of the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (12 U.S.C. 5371(b)(5)(C)) is amended by inserting or small savings and loan holding company after any small bank holding company.
For the purposes of this title:

subsection.text: The term bank holding company has the same meaning as in section 2 of the Bank Holding Company Act of 1956 ( 12 U.S.C. 1841 ).
The term savings and loan holding company has the same meaning as in section 10(a) of the Home Owners' Loan Act ( 12 U.S.C. 1467a(a) ).

paragraph.text: in subparagraph (E)(vi)(II), by striking a limit set by the Board and inserting 1,000 per year; and
by inserting after subparagraph (E) the following:

subparagraph.text: The term rural means any area other than—

clause.text: a city or town that has a population of greater than 50,000 inhabitants; and
any urbanized area contiguous and adjacent to a city or town described in clause (i).

paragraph.header: Coverage for interest on lawyers trust accounts and other similar escrow accounts

subparagraph.text: The Administration shall provide pass-through share insurance for the deposits or shares of any interest on lawyers trust account (commonly referred to as IOLTA) or other similar escrow accounts.

clause.text: For share insurance purposes, IOLTAs are treated as escrow accounts.

IOLTAs and other similar escrow accounts are considered member accounts for purposes of paragraph (1), if the attorney administering the IOLTA or the escrow agent administering the escrow account is a member of the insured credit union in which the funds are held.

The terms interest on lawyers trust account or IOLTA mean a system in which lawyers place certain client funds in interest-bearing or dividend-bearing accounts, with the interest or dividends then used to fund programs such as legal service organizations who provide services to clients in need.

The term pass-through share insurance means, with respect to IOLTAs and other similar escrow accounts, insurance coverage based on the interest of each person on whose behalf funds are held in such accounts by the attorney administering the IOLTA or the escrow agent administering a similar escrow account, in accordance with regulations issued by the Administration.

subparagraph.text: No provision of this paragraph shall be construed as authorizing an insured credit union to accept the deposits of an IOLTA or similar escrow account in an amount greater than such credit union is authorized to accept under any other provision of Federal or State law.
